misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the provided loop structure correctly shifts all elements one position to the right while preserving the value of the original last element to be placed at the first position. They appear to understand the requirement and have implemented the standard algorithm for a right array rotation.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no conceptual gap related to a flawed mental model of the notional machine. The student's code correctly implements the specified right shift (circular rotation) for an array of size 'n'. This involves storing the last element, then iterating backward from n-1 down to 1, shifting arr[i-1] into arr[i], and finally placing the stored last element into arr[0].
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None. The code is logically correct based on the problem description.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the standard iterative mechanism for performing a right shift on an array (storing the last element, then iterating backward to move elements one position right, and finally placing the stored element at index 0) is sufficient and correctly implemented in their code.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no significant conceptual gap or misconception regarding the notional machine in this specific implementation. The student has correctly modeled the required array mutation process: handling the wrap-around element first, then shifting intermediate elements without overwriting unshifted data, and finally placing the wrapped element.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None (The code is logically correct and produces the expected output for the sample case.)
